itemRows.title: Introduction
itemRows.content:
“Point of View is worth 80 IQ points”
—Alan Kay

When Covid arrived, many of us went on a learning frenzy. Now with the situation in the Ukraine, we find ourselves trying to understand what’s happening and the history that led up to it. I’m fascinated to realize how much I’m relying on text — articles, essays, twitter feeds etc. — to provide the nuanced exploration of complex and abstract ideas i’m looking for, practically in real-time. Video may help me identify with the suffering of the Ukranian people, but it seems to skim along the surface, manipulating emotions rather than digging deep for understanding.

Yesterday I read four articles, quite different in perspective and even topic, which I thought gave me some insight into what’s going on. What’s remarkable is that when compared to the limited range of voices of the pre-internet era, these four articles are only a tiny fraction of the breathtaking range of voices now available on the internet. And this is right on time because the complexity of the current moment is such that we need a broad array of lenses through which we can look; not that truth is relative, but rather that truth is inevitably a collage of perspectives which depend on the collision of multiple viewpoints.

Thanks to the Internet Archive’s Wayback Machine, I’m putting the four articles here for two reasons. Some of you may find them interesting and worth the read. And also, as a way of connecting to the ongoing conversation about the evolution of media in the networked era. What better time to talk than right now when we’re in the middle of it.
References:
Which was archived because of several cool archiving projects:
And this Tweet:

itemRows.title: Saved from the Fire: a Triangle Employee Escapes
itemRows.content:
Ida Seltzer recalls being spared the fate of many of her co-workers during the great Triangle Shirtwaist Company fire in March 1911. She had been fired only the before for refusing to work because her father was ill.

Seltzer: In 1911 I went into work to the Triangle and at that time, I made there already $12 a week. The shop there, was tremendous, it was three or four flights. In the shop, you know, we were piecework. It was very, very hard work. And it was in a terrible, terrible sweatshop. It was absolutely unbearable. Production there was like, they were standing in the back of you, and watching you every minute, what you worked and they drive like a slave. The doors were locked. No fire escape.

Every night, when we used to go out of the shop, it used to be a group of girls are there from the shop, like you know, hired that they should examine you, your bosom, your panties, you’re anything, if you don’t take out any lace, or cotton, or a blouse. They used to, the men used to be examined and the women used to be examined.

At that time, it was on Friday and I couldn’t work overtime — my father was very sick, really sick, he got emphysema and he coughed an awful lot, and I had a lot of problems and couldn’t work, you know, overtime. They expected me to work. So I came to the foreman and I said to him, “I can’t work overtime, I. . . “ He said, “Get out! And don’t come back in tomorrow.” so I didn’t, so I went out . . .

Interviewer: How much time of overtime where are you expected to work?

Seltzer: well, you hadda work, you used to work from six till eight o’clock. You know, till you get home, it was nine o’clock, because the walking home two hours . . .

Interviewer: and what kind of work did you do there, specifically?

Seltzer: Specif . . . a machine. You know, working a machine, blouses. And I came home. And tomorrow was the fire. And that time, I’ll never forget it. I . . . you sit with young people nine months, machine by machine you know. Others, the right machine is from this side, and across the way it was another machine. And you got acquainted for nine months with young people. They had, some of them, had diamond rings - they're supposed to get married in June. The boys used to work daytime and go at night to school and they had the hopes they’ll be an engineer, they’ll be a doctor, they’ll be a lawyer – they’ll be something. You know, young, intelligent children, each and everyone of them, was no dumbbells.

And the fire broke out. They locked, the doors were locked. There was no fire escape we had to escape, or no door to open. 146 children were burned and not to recognize and except…

Hundreds and hundreds of people were taken to the hospitals. They spraying from the windows, down, you know? Oh, it was a tragedy for years and years.

The Immigrant Experience, produced by Gail Pellet (New York: WBAI, 1976).

Introduction
itemRows.content: I went and searched the Internet Archive for Emily Dickinson's poem "Faith is a Fine Invention" curious about how much diversity there might be in the results. For a very familiar poem, there's a surprising amount of variation!

itemRows.title: Item 3
itemRows.content:
A 1996 edition of Dickinson. Here we have some italics and capitals and a dash, the editor maybe having gone back to the original. "Faith" is in quotation marks.

What's also interesting here is that the second line is different: "when Gentlemen can see," not "for Gentlemen who see".

itemRows.title: Item 5
itemRows.content: An issue of Mad from June 1972 shows Pope Paul VI peering through a microscope.

itemRows.title: Item 7
itemRows.content: An anthology from 1994 has no italics, no quotation marks, no capitalized words.

itemRows.title: Item 9
itemRows.content: Monarch Notes normalizes Dickinson in quoting her: her words don't look any different than the academic writing around them.

itemRows.title: Item 11
itemRows.content:
Mabel Loomis Todd's 1893 edition of Dickinson's poem, ostensibly where most of these came from. Note the lack of capitalization; nobody follows the initial dropcap and small caps, and the French spacing before the exclamation point seems like a dead-end.

There are no quotation marks around "Faith".

itemRows.title: Item 13
itemRows.content: A 1964 edition goes back to the first word in small caps.

itemRows.title: Item 15
itemRows.content: Another Selected Poems from 1997. This one has the italics and the dash, though it's not identical: there's also a space before the dash.

itemRows.title: Item 16
itemRows.content: The Harvard Medical Alumni Bulletin from 1982 decides to forego punctuation and capitalization and italicize the whole thing.

itemRows.title: WikiSource, 2008
itemRows.content: In 2008, WikiSource italicized Microscopes but not "see" and had a space before the dash. There are no exclamation marks. The second line is "When Gentlemen can see —".

itemRows.title: Item 20
itemRows.content: By 2020, Wikisource had italicized see as well as Microscopes and also dropped a dash and added some exclamation marks. There are quotation marks, but in the second line, the older "For Gentlemen who see!" is being used.

itemRows.title: First Amendment
itemRows.content: Congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion, or prohibiting the free exercise thereof; or abridging the freedom of speech, or of the press; or the right of the people peaceably to assemble, and to petition the Government for a redress of grievances.

itemRows.title: Second Amendment
itemRows.content: A well regulated Militia, being necessary to the security of a free State, the right of the people to keep and bear Arms, shall not be infringed.

itemRows.title: Third Amendment
itemRows.content: No Soldier shall, in time of peace be quartered in any house, without the consent of the Owner, nor in time of war, but in a manner to be prescribed by law.

itemRows.title: Fourth Amendment
itemRows.content: The right of the people to be secure in their persons, houses, papers, and effects, against unreasonable searches and seizures, shall not be violated, and no Warrants shall issue, but upon probable cause, supported by Oath or affirmation, and particularly describing the place to be searched, and the persons or things to be seized.

itemRows.title: Fifth Amendment
itemRows.content: No person shall be held to answer for a capital, or otherwise infamous crime, unless on a presentment or indictment of a Grand Jury, except in cases arising in the land or naval forces, or in the Militia, when in actual service in time of War or public danger; nor shall any person be subject for the same offence to be twice put in jeopardy of life or limb; nor shall be compelled in any criminal case to be a witness against himself, nor be deprived of life, liberty, or property, without due process of law; nor shall private property be taken for public use, without just compensation.

itemRows.title: New Item
itemRows.content: McLuhan once said ‘we’re driving faster and faster into the future but steering only by looking through the rear-view mirror.’ And we can think of a corner being turned into the actual modern era. I just gave a talk in Korea whose title was The computer revolution hasn’t happened yet. I would say that it won’t have happened until people start using the computer to start dealing with thought vectors and concept space and dealing with the idea that you can have active dynamic models of the things your trying to represent.”

itemRows.title: The book of probes : Marshall McLuhan, David Carson
Item 1
itemRows.content:
In 1995 MIT and Brown University sponsored a symposium honoring the work of Vannevar Bush. Alan Kay’s presentation focused on the contributions of the early pioneers whose work in the 60s had been inspired in part by Vannevar Bush’s seminal 1945 article, As We May Think.

To explore, click the links.

itemRows.title: Alan Kay quote
itemRows.content: “Knowing more than your own field is really helpful. I’ve always thought one of the reasons the 60s was interesting is that no one was a computer scientist back then. And everyone who came into it, came in with lots of other knowledge and interests. Because of that, when they tried to figure out what computers were, the only place they could go to for analogies were other areas, so we got some extremely interesting ideas from that.”

itemRows.title: Mindstorms: children, computers, and powerful ideas
Alan Kay discusses the role of JCR Licklider and ARPA
itemRows.thumbnail: https://ia601409.us.archive.org/3/items/alan-kay-discusses-marvin-minsky-at-mit-symposium-on-vannevar-bush-1995/Alan Kay discusses Marvin Minsky at MIT symposium on  Vannevar Bush 1995.mov

itemRows.title: Item 8
itemRows.content: “Typical Marvin comment: ‘You don’t understand anything if you only understand it one way’”

itemRows.title: Item 3
itemRows.content:
Movie Manual

When I first saw Dave Backer's Movie Manual at MIT it blew my mind on two counts. Anti-aliasing had just been developed in the lab and this was the first time anyone had seen decent looking text on a TV screen (the quality of the video doesn’t come close to how good it looked in situ). Also the first time the video appears on what otherwise looks like a normal book page (about 2:20 in the video) it expanded our notion of the page to include audio and video — i.e. the affordances of a book but with the addition of time-based media.

itemRows.content:
“I think it's true of most of the people i think of as the great people in the 60s is that they really wanted it all.”

—Alan remarking on the early pioneer’s expansive view of what was possible and important.

itemRows.title: Alan Kay discusses Ivan Sutherland & Sketchpad
Some Reflections On Early History By J. C. R. Licklider ( VPRI 0093)
Item 8
itemRows.content: Alan Kay on ARPA: “Their basic idea was to fund people instead of projects — one of the great ideas of all time — and fund directions instead of goals. I don’t think anyone else would have funded Engelbart in those days. It’s a real pity that the ARPA funding from the 60s didn’t carry over to the 70s; if it had i think history would have been quite different today. Becuase sometimes the people who can see the farthest are the ones who are the most difficult for the bean counters to understand”

itemRows.title: Introduction
itemRows.content:
There are a number of segments in which the stamp “FAKE” is emblazoned over images of dead bodies in Bucha and other images, including Zelenskyy.

One short segment includes footage from a Live For America interview of Marjorie Taylor Greene by Jeremy Herrell in which she is heard to say, “They have been calling us Nazis for past 5 years, guess what there are real Nazis in Ukraine” “The Democrats are courting real Nazis in Ukraine.”

Background on these new collections

Mindful of the ravages of the war in Ukraine and state controlled Russian media’s agendas, we are not planning to bring widespread attention to these archival research offerings. However, we welcome journalists and other researchers to explore what we are offering and would appreciate feedback on how we can better meet their needs.

Unlike the TV News Archive, the three Russian language channels are not searchable by captions. There are no captions, we don’t have Russian-to-English speech-to-text software. Currently, there is a 12-hour lag between broadcast time and availability for viewing. We don’t have program title information, so we divide all the broadcast content into 1/2-hour increments. We offer thumbnail images for each 1-minute segment.

  • Russia-1 TV collection (12-hr delay in playability)
  • NTV collection (12-hr delay in playability)
  • Channel One collection (12-hr delay in playability)

itemRows.title: Item 1
itemRows.content:
If the United States had a tradition of recognizing individuals as "national treasures," media archaeologist, Rick Prelinger would be one of my first nominees. Over the decades Rick rescued 60,000 industrial and educational films, many literally from the dumpster, that together tell a story which is quite different than the "official" Hollywood version. What Rick understood was that the narrative in these "ephemeral" films, which were never intended to be saved for future watching. . . was in many ways a more honest portrayal of the culture than the comedies and dramas on TV and movie screens.

Rick gave his collection to the Library of Congress and also made much of it available at the Internet Archive. But before that, Rick curated a two-hour collection of films which shine a light on the darkness of mid-20th century American culture. Voyager published these on laserdisc and videotape in 1988 and on CD-ROM in the early 90s.

itemRows.title: Item 6
itemRows.content: “Papert had another profound idea. Whatever the computer was it wasn’t really a tool or even a vehicle in the sense of being an automobile as compared to IBM’s railroads. Papert thought of it as being a medium for powerful ideas”

itemRows.title: Item 4
itemRows.content: “What Engelbart brought was not just a vision of interacting with a system, but he had a philosophical underpinning.”

itemRows.title: Bob Stein introduces Rick Prelinger's Ephemeral Films project
Zoodoo
itemRows.content: Zoodoo was Alex Itin’s first work in TK3. Voyager had published a poetry anthology by Ron Mann featuring 24 poets performing their work often, as was the case with Amiri Baraka with musical accompaniment. Alex took the film’s audio track and added a series of paintings inspired by words. The rhythm of Baraka’s delivery allowed the user a moment to look at the painting and then reveal the text of the next stanza.

itemRows.title: Bob Stein Introduces The TK 3 Work Of Alex Itin
Item 6
itemRows.content:
arc along the watchtower

arc along the watchtower is Alex’s most complex TK3 work — two brothers confront the reality of their father’s death told in alternating spurts of film, painting and audio.  two versions below, the first simply goes page by page letting the video on each page play to the end before proceeding; the other just the paintings with their bits of the conversation.

itemRows.title: Item 8
itemRows.content:
Morococo

Words and Paintings by Alex Itin, Music by Javier Hernandez Miyares. The reader can go page by page sequentially or click on hot spots which make pre-ordained hyper-jumps through the text.

Alex’s statement about Morocco

Morococo was a text from an Arabic school book.  Arabic is beautiful even if illegible to me. Calligraphy.  Calligraffiti.  I had this sense that what I loved about American painting had come out of a sort of perverse intellectual reaction to WW2.  There was the expressionism of German painting mixed with the zen gestural brush work of illegible Japanese poetry.  You become the enemy you kill.  You become the New York School. I imagined white intellectuals at say Columbia hired by the OSS to translate German and Japanese going down town to drink with the painters at the cedar bar listening to Jazz and trying to wrap their heads around the enemy and I imagined a Dutch like deKooning could be a nexus for Americans to get it or if not get it but feel it.  In the way that jazz can be felt pentatonic to 12 note scale.l. Blue Bach.  It was a mourning for the dead ones you had to kill.  Or so I thought and to be frank still do.respect the dead.  Respect your enemy.  Respect your enemy’s dead.  Try to sing a song about it.  It’s kind of that simple.

I’d graduated from college into the IRAQ war.  This unknown known was on my head and I could feel it was the crisis point of my generation that is called X.  I’d read John Mcafee’s book on the Arc of Binding Energy and had a real sense that there was a thing in the wind.   It was coming.  It came,  but not as bad as I was fearing.  But still the anxiety of history turning.

itemRows.title: Item 11
itemRows.content:
A note about what TK3 could and could not do.

The goal of TK3 was to enable anyone to assemble media elements via simple drag and drop. Although the TK3 authoring environment provided pre-defined templates, in terms of graphic design, users had complete control over every single pixel, even to the extent of designing custom looks for each of the the built in tools (navigation, search, note-taking etc.) One important feature TK3 lacked was the ability to turn pages according to a time-line. Thus in the Alex Itin works shown here, the page turns are not automatic.

itemRows.title: Item 11
itemRows.content:
Alex’s Introduction

Where was I:  When I got to New York after fleeing Connecticut death I was temping at a grey ad agency and in Park Slope and I had musician friends from Dumbo who would do DJ events and live music and I found myself reworking the figurative language idea with books I found in the streets of Brooklyn.  In those days all writers lived in Park Slope and their libraries over flowed to their neighbors by way of the stoops and sidewalks.  In some ways Park Slope was an enormous lending library, but always there was the rain.  I’d seen holocausts of drowned books.  It did not seem such a sin to take them and use them as room to rehearse the figure.

I had a deal with myself then and partly now and this slows me down but, if I hadn’t read it and loved it I couldn’t kill it.  I could only draw in books I loved. I was an old yeller even in my youth.  So I did a long series of drawing nights at the Galapagos club in Williamsburg where I would take a text:  say Frankenstein on Halloween and try to draw the room.  Everyone in it.  It had some relation to Joyce and the idea that if you put a focus on anyone on the street there was a novel there.  We are all a great epic story and also I suppose sort of boring and a sameness of crowd. Also if you obscured some or most of the text a randomly generated poem would appear in the margins. It was  maybe Bowie by Burroughs by way of the Dadas….. or the obvious.  Anyway if you knew the book even just a few of the words would glow with the nostalgia of a lost love, or so I supposed.  The DJ said this is so great because no one reads anymore.

I would attempt to sell these pages for 5 dollars which was the price of a beer at Galapagos. Mostly people just bought me a beer and took a page as souvenir,  or just bought me a  beer and listened to me talk.  There was a large element of performance;  some didacticism,  some advocacy for things I liked.  I hoped people who took a page would feel compelled to read the book it was on.  This was naive I think and not all that many took pages any way so soon I had a large library of drawings.

I met Bob Stein at an open studios event where I’d put up an epic floor to ceiling wall installation all these book pages.  The building was a gun power labyrinth of GET SMART passages and doors and long halls.  I don’t think he saw the installation,  but he found me drawing in the pages of Hemingway at the bar in my friends loft.  He said, “You are the guy I’m looking for”.

I said, “what do you mean?”

He said, “I’m a digital publisher.

I said, “Oh I think you’re the guy I’m looking for”

Because earlier a DJ had told me everything should be on the computer.

itemRows.title: Arc Along The Watchtower Stills + Audio
Item 1
itemRows.content:
HYPERCARD:

Steve Jobs Killed It . . . But not in a good way

Apple's introduction of HyperCard at Macworld in August 1987 wins my vote for one of the most exciting events in computing history. Bill Atkinson, HyperCard's architect, wanted to democratize computing by creating a platform for ordinary people to “make things.” Hypercard, enabled users to create stacks of (virtual) cards which could be linked to each other in different ways. The six buttons in the photo, celebrating the idea of linking one idea to another (hypertext)were given away at the Macworld launch.

Teachers were the first to glom onto HyperCard, yielding an explosion of creativity as tens of thousands of non-programmers were suddenly empowered to assemble credible content on their own.

Much of HyperCard's power came from Dan Winkler's plain-english programming language — HyperTalk. I'll never forget my own glee when I made a button to advance to the next page by simply adding the simple script "Go Next Card" to a graphic of a forward facing arrow. This was heady stuff for someone who practically failed "physics for poets." Nothing I ever made with HyperCard was good enough to publish, but I was able to create first drafts which my dear colleagues Steve Riggins (and later Colin Holgate) turned into something useful and wonderful. I'll make separate entries later on for some of the things we made.

Two more things:

Bill Atkinson said that the idea for HyperCard came to him during an acid trip.

One of the very first things Steve Jobs did when he returned to Apple was to kill HyperCard. It was a sad day and I trust history will judge him harshly for this.

Item 6
itemRows.content: The very first electronic books were created in HyperCard in 1992. The first three were Douglas Adams' Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy, Martin Gardner's Annotated Alice in Wonderland and Michael Crichton's Jurassic Park. Douglas Adams' created an audio promo which many years later was attached to the animation on the right.

itemRows.title: Item 4
itemRows.content:
The collected thoughts from people responding to Jaron Lanier’s essay are not a hive mind, but they’ve done a better job of dissecting his provocative essay than any one of us could have done. Which is precisely the point.

Dan Gilmor

itemRows.title: Item 5
itemRows.content:
Clay Shirky has written an excellent rebuttal of Jaron Lanier’s wrong-headed critique of collaborative peer production on the Internet: “Digital Maoism: The Hazards of the New Online Collectivism.” Shirky’s response is one of about a dozen just posted on Edge.org, which also published Lanier’s essay.
Shirky begins by taking down Lanier’s straw man, the cliché of the “hive mind,” or mob, that propels collective enterprises like Wikipedia: “…the target of the piece, the hive mind, is just a catchphrase, used by people who don’t understand how things like Wikipedia really work.”

itemRows.content: The world is everything that is the case.
The world is the totality of facts, not of things.
The world is determined by the facts, and by these being all the facts.
For the totality of facts determines both what is the case, and also all that is not the case.
The facts in logical space are the world.
The world divides into facts.
Any one can either be the case or not be the case, and everything else remains the same.
What is the case, the fact, is the existence of atomic facts.
The logical picture of the facts is the thought.
The thought is the significant proposition.

Propositions are truth-functions of elementary propositions.

(An elementary proposition is a truth-function of itself.)

The general form of truth-function is: [p, ξ, N(ξ)].

This is the general form of a proposition.
Whereof one cannot speak, thereof one must be silent.

itemRows.title: First Amendment
itemRows.content: Congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion, or prohibiting the free exercise thereof; or abridging the freedom of speech, or of the press; or the right of the people peaceably to assemble, and to petition the Government for a redress of grievances.

itemRows.title: Second Amendment
itemRows.content: A well regulated Militia, being necessary to the security of a free State, the right of the people to keep and bear Arms, shall not be infringed.

itemRows.title: Third Amendment
itemRows.content: No Soldier shall, in time of peace be quartered in any house, without the consent of the Owner, nor in time of war, but in a manner to be prescribed by law.

itemRows.title: Fourth Amendment
itemRows.content: The right of the people to be secure in their persons, houses, papers, and effects, against unreasonable searches and seizures, shall not be violated, and no Warrants shall issue, but upon probable cause, supported by Oath or affirmation, and particularly describing the place to be searched, and the persons or things to be seized.

itemRows.title: Fifth Amendment
itemRows.content: No person shall be held to answer for a capital, or otherwise infamous crime, unless on a presentment or indictment of a Grand Jury, except in cases arising in the land or naval forces, or in the Militia, when in actual service in time of War or public danger; nor shall any person be subject for the same offence to be twice put in jeopardy of life or limb; nor shall be compelled in any criminal case to be a witness against himself, nor be deprived of life, liberty, or property, without due process of law; nor shall private property be taken for public use, without just compensation.

itemRows.title: First Amendment
itemRows.content: Congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion, or prohibiting the free exercise thereof; or abridging the freedom of speech, or of the press; or the right of the people peaceably to assemble, and to petition the Government for a redress of grievances.

itemRows.title: Second Amendment
itemRows.content: A well regulated Militia, being necessary to the security of a free State, the right of the people to keep and bear Arms, shall not be infringed.

itemRows.title: Third Amendment
itemRows.content: No Soldier shall, in time of peace be quartered in any house, without the consent of the Owner, nor in time of war, but in a manner to be prescribed by law.

itemRows.title: Fourth Amendment
itemRows.content: The right of the people to be secure in their persons, houses, papers, and effects, against unreasonable searches and seizures, shall not be violated, and no Warrants shall issue, but upon probable cause, supported by Oath or affirmation, and particularly describing the place to be searched, and the persons or things to be seized.

itemRows.title: Fifth Amendment
itemRows.content: No person shall be held to answer for a capital, or otherwise infamous crime, unless on a presentment or indictment of a Grand Jury, except in cases arising in the land or naval forces, or in the Militia, when in actual service in time of War or public danger; nor shall any person be subject for the same offence to be twice put in jeopardy of life or limb; nor shall be compelled in any criminal case to be a witness against himself, nor be deprived of life, liberty, or property, without due process of law; nor shall private property be taken for public use, without just compensation.

itemRows.title: Item 1
itemRows.content:
In 1995 MIT and Brown University sponsored a symposium honoring the work of Vannevar Bush. Alan Kay’s presentation focused on the contributions of the early pioneers whose work in the 60s had been inspired in part by Vannevar Bush’s seminal 1945 article, As We May Think.

To explore, click the links.

itemRows.title: Alan Kay quote
itemRows.content: “Knowing more than your own field is really helpful. I’ve always thought one of the reasons the 60s was interesting is that no one was a computer scientist back then. And everyone who came into it, came in with lots of other knowledge and interests. Because of that, when they tried to figure out what computers were, the only place they could go to for analogies were other areas, so we got some extremely interesting ideas from that.”

itemRows.title: Introduction
itemRows.content:
There are a number of segments in which the stamp “FAKE” is emblazoned over images of dead bodies in Bucha and other images, including Zelenskyy.

One short segment includes footage from a Live For America interview of Marjorie Taylor Greene by Jeremy Herrell in which she is heard to say, “They have been calling us Nazis for past 5 years, guess what there are real Nazis in Ukraine” “The Democrats are courting real Nazis in Ukraine.”

Background on these new collections

Mindful of the ravages of the war in Ukraine and state controlled Russian media’s agendas, we are not planning to bring widespread attention to these archival research offerings. However, we welcome journalists and other researchers to explore what we are offering and would appreciate feedback on how we can better meet their needs.

Unlike the TV News Archive, the three Russian language channels are not searchable by captions. There are no captions, we don’t have Russian-to-English speech-to-text software. Currently, there is a 12-hour lag between broadcast time and availability for viewing. We don’t have program title information, so we divide all the broadcast content into 1/2-hour increments. We offer thumbnail images for each 1-minute segment.

  • Russia-1 TV collection (12-hr delay in playability)
  • NTV collection (12-hr delay in playability)
  • Channel One collection (12-hr delay in playability)

itemRows.content: • This 800K file is the only example of crossmedia psychotronic beliefware currently extant. The original program was found by Mr. Hardiker in Babelian ruins dated 9999 BC & deciphered from a since forgotten machine language. It is thought that Zaum Gadget was a subliminal event-structure capable of subtly manipulating the beliefs of any participant. A maze of twisted sound effects, extant texts, & interactive visuals.

itemRows.title: Bob Stein Introduces The TK 3 Work Of Alex Itin
Item 2
itemRows.content:
What TK3 could and could not do.

The goal of TK3 was to enable anyone to assemble media elements via simple drag and drop. Although TK3 provided pre-defined templates, users had complete control over every single pixel, even to the extent of designing custom looks for the the built in tools (navigation, search, note-taking etc.) One feature TK3 lacked was the ability to turn pages according to a time-line. Thus in the works shown here, the page turns are not automatic.

itemRows.title: Item 4
itemRows.content:
Zoodoo

Zoodoo was Alex Itin’s first work in TK3. Voyager had published a poetry anthology by Ron Mann featuring 24 poets performing their work often, as was the case with Amiri Baraka with musical accompaniment. Alex took the film’s audio track and added a series of paintings inspired by words. The rhythm of Baraka’s delivery allowed the user a moment to look at the painting and then reveal the text of the next stanza.

itemRows.title: Morcocco
itemRows.content:
Morocco

Words and Paintings by Alex Itin, Music by Javier Hernandez Miyares. The reader can go page by page sequentially or click on hot spots which make pre-ordained hyper-jumps through the text.

Alex’s statement about Morocco

Morococo was a text from an Arabic school book.  Arabic is beautiful even if illegible to me. Calligraphy.  Calligraffiti.  I had this sense that what I loved about American painting had come out of a sort of perverse intellectual reaction to WW2.  There was the expressionism of German painting mixed with the zen gestural brush work of illegible Japanese poetry.  You become the enemy you kill.  You become the New York School. I imagined white intellectuals at say Columbia hired by the OSS to translate German and Japanese going down town to drink with the painters at the cedar bar listening to Jazz and trying to wrap their heads around the enemy and I imagined a Dutch like deKooning could be a nexus for Americans to get it or if not get it but feel it.  In the way that jazz can be felt pentatonic to 12 note scale.l. Blue Bach.  It was a mourning for the dead ones you had to kill.  Or so I thought and to be frank still do.respect the dead.  Respect your enemy.  Respect your enemy’s dead.  Try to sing a song about it.  It’s kind of that simple.

I’d graduated from college into the IRAQ war.  This unknown known was on my head and I could feel it was the crisis point of my generation that is called X.  I’d read John Mcafee’s book on the Arc of Binding Energy and had a real sense that there was a thing in the wind.   It was coming.  It came,  but not as bad as I was fearing.  But still the anxiety of history turning.

itemRows.title: Item 7
itemRows.content:
Asi Nisi Masa

Asi Nisi Masa is Alex’s homage to cinema in general and to his favorite eight and a half films, the half being the short children’s film, The Red Balloon; the others — Citizen Kane, 2001: A Space Odyssey, The Third Man, Wild Strawberries, Rear Window, Rashomon, Taxi Driver and 8 1/2. Several years later, Alex used the TK3 version of Asi Nisi Masa as a central prop or character in a live performance in which he told a haunting story of his father’s death.  The video of that performance is posted below the video of the TK3 work.

itemRows.title: Item 9
itemRows.content:
Odd City

Odd City can be played straight through, propelled by Charles Mingus’ soundtrack, Goodbye Pork Pie Hat, (first video)  or click on hot spots to reveal additional layers along the way, (second video)

itemRows.title: Item 13
itemRows.content:
arc along the watchtower

Arc Along the Watchtower is Alex’s most complex TK3 work — two brothers confront the reality of their father’s death told in alternating spurts of film, painting and audio. The first version goes page by page with all the video; the other is shorter as it proceeds with just the paintings and the audio.

itemRows.title: Introduction
itemRows.content: You will find NINE different versions of the African folktale of "the jealous brother" in this display. Here is a quick guide to the stories:

itemRows.title: The Murder of Maciloniane
itemRows.content: 1. This is the oldest recorded version of the story, first published in 1859 in a book, Les Bassoutos (The Basutos) by Eugene Casalis, a missionary in Lesotho in southern Africa. In this Sotho version, the younger brother obtains cattle from a monstrous giant and is murdered by his jealous older brother. The younger brother is then reborn as a bird who reports the crime that his brother committed.

itemRows.title: Masilo le Masilonyane / Masilo and Masilonyane
itemRows.content: 4. The next published version comes from 1908 in The Treasury of Basuto Lore published in the Sotho language with an English translation by Edouard Jacottet, a missionary in Lesotho. The version reported by Jacottet is very close to the version reported by Casalis fifty years earlier but, unlike Casalis, Jacottet includes the Sotho language version of the story.

itemRows.title: Masilo, Masilonyane, and the Old Woman.
itemRows.content: 6. We now jump some decades ahead in time to a version of the story published in Afrikaans by the South African writer Minnie Postma in 1964, based on a story she heard growing up in Lesotho. Postma's book was translated into English and published in 1974. The remarkable feature of this book is the killer ostriches, characters who are not found in any other recorded version of the story at the Internet Archive.

itemRows.title: Masilo and Masilonyane
itemRows.content: 7. Like Minnie Postma, the South African writer Phyllis Savory published versions of folktales that she remembered hearing in her childhood. The story of the jealous brother that Savory tells comes from Lesotho, and it features an illustration by Jillian Hulme, making it the first illustrated version of the story that you can find at the Internet Archive. In Savory's version of the story, the younger brother survives and the two brothers are reconciled in the end.

itemRows.title: Masilo and Masilonyana
itemRows.content: 9. Remember the version of the story from Botswana with the snake? In this version of the story from Lesotho as told by South African storyteller Gcina Mhlophe, you will again see a supernatural snake who makes it possible for the younger brother to survive the murder attempt by his jealous older brother. Be sure to look at the illustrations by Rachel Griffin that show the mysterious old woman's supernatural fingernails, and also the younger brother inside the snake!

itemRows.title: Two Boys Set Out to Find Work
itemRows.content: 8. This highly abbreviated version of the story was recorded by anthropologist Harold Scheub in 1967 in the Eastern Cape of South Africa (bordering on Lesotho); the storyteller is a woman of the AmaHlubi tribe, and Scheub reports both the Xhosa language version along with an English translation. Although the boys are not brothers and there is no supernatural monster in this story, the plot of jealousy plays out in the same way: the jealous older boy murders the younger boy, and a tell-tale bird denounces his crime to the people of the village.

itemRows.title: Izelamani / The Two Brothers
itemRows.content: 2. itemRows.title: Introduction
itemRows.content: You will find NINE different versions of the African folktale of "the jealous brother" in this display. Here is a quick guide to the stories:

itemRows.title: The Murder of Maciloniane
itemRows.content: 1. This is the oldest recorded version of the story, first published in 1859 in a book, Les Bassoutos (The Basutos) by Eugene Casalis, a missionary in Lesotho in southern Africa. In this Sotho version, the younger brother obtains cattle from a monstrous giant and is murdered by his jealous older brother. The younger brother is then reborn as a bird who reports the crime that his brother committed.

itemRows.title: Masilo le Masilonyane / Masilo and Masilonyane
itemRows.content: 4. The next published version comes from 1908 in The Treasury of Basuto Lore published in the Sotho language with an English translation by Edouard Jacottet, a missionary in Lesotho. The version reported by Jacottet is very close to the version reported by Casalis fifty years earlier but, unlike Casalis, Jacottet includes the Sotho language version of the story.

itemRows.title: Masilo, Masilonyane, and the Old Woman.
itemRows.content: 6. We now jump some decades ahead in time to a version of the story published in Afrikaans by the South African writer Minnie Postma in 1964, based on a story she heard growing up in Lesotho. Postma's book was translated into English and published in 1974. The remarkable feature of this book is the killer ostriches, characters who are not found in any other recorded version of the story at the Internet Archive.

itemRows.title: Masilo and Masilonyane
itemRows.content: 7. Like Minnie Postma, the South African writer Phyllis Savory published versions of folktales that she remembered hearing in her childhood. The story of the jealous brother that Savory tells comes from Lesotho, and it features an illustration by Jillian Hulme, making it the first illustrated version of the story that you can find at the Internet Archive. In Savory's version of the story, the younger brother survives and the two brothers are reconciled in the end.

itemRows.title: Masilo and Masilonyana
itemRows.content: 9. Remember the version of the story from Botswana with the snake? In this version of the story from Lesotho as told by South African storyteller Gcina Mhlophe, you will again see a supernatural snake who makes it possible for the younger brother to survive the murder attempt by his jealous older brother. Be sure to look at the illustrations by Rachel Griffin that show the mysterious old woman's supernatural fingernails, and also the younger brother inside the snake!

itemRows.title: Two Boys Set Out to Find Work
itemRows.content: 8. This highly abbreviated version of the story was recorded by anthropologist Harold Scheub in 1967 in the Eastern Cape of South Africa (bordering on Lesotho); the storyteller is a woman of the AmaHlubi tribe, and Scheub reports both the Xhosa language version along with an English translation. Although the boys are not brothers and there is no supernatural monster in this story, the plot of jealousy plays out in the same way: the jealous older boy murders the younger boy, and a tell-tale bird denounces his crime to the people of the village.

itemRows.title: Izelamani / The Two Brothers
itemRows.content: 2. In this version, the younger brother obtains the cattle from a mysterious old woman, and this time he survives the murder attempt by his jealous older brother, thanks to a tell-tale bird.

itemRows.title: Masilo le Masiloyane / Masilo and Masiloyane
itemRows.content: 3. The next version comes from what is now Botswana, and it was published in 1879 in the Setswana language along with an English translation. As in the Zulu version, the younger brother gets the cattle from a mysterious old woman, not from a monstrous giant, but as in the Sotho version, the younger brother does not survive.

itemRows.title: Masilo and Masilonyane
itemRows.content: 5. This is another version of the story as told in Botswana, and it was published by Tom Brown, a missionary, in 1926. This version is quite different from the previously published versions of the story because it features a supernatural snake who is responsible for the younger brother's survival; there is no tell-tale bird in this version of the story.

itemRows.title: Item 2
itemRows.content: And here we are already, starting the October calendar for Anansi Book Club (plus you can see all the Anansi Book Club posts at this blog). Our first book this month is Mrs. Chicken and the Hungry Crocodile by Won Ldy-Paye and Margaret Lippert, just a click away at the Internet Archive.

itemRows.title: Mrs. Chicken and the hungry crocodile
Item 4
itemRows.content: The beautiful illustrations for this book are by Julie Paschkis, and you can see how the illustrations, text, layout, everything works together, as in this 2-page spread:

itemRows.title: Item 5
itemRows.content: You might remember that we read a collaboration by Ldy-Paye, Lippert, and Paschkis several months ago, back in June: The Talking Vegetables.

itemRows.title: Item 8
itemRows.content:
One of my favorite things about this book is that Ldy-Paye lets us know that he learned this story from his grandmother, who told him other stories from the Dan storytelling traditions of Liberia.

I also want to note that you can find the story of Mrs. Chicken, basically the same but with some different wording in the collection of Dan stories from Liberia that Won Ldy-Paye and Margaret Lippert wrote with illustrations by Ashley Bryan: Why Leopard Has Spots.

itemRows.title: Mrs. Chicken and the hungry crocodile
Item 4
itemRows.content: The beautiful illustrations for this book are by Julie Paschkis, and you can see how the illustrations, text, layout, everything works together, as in this 2-page spread:

itemRows.title: Item 8
itemRows.content:
One of my favorite things about this book is that Ldy-Paye lets us know that he learned this story from his grandmother, who told him other stories from the Dan storytelling traditions of Liberia.

I also want to note that you can find the story of Mrs. Chicken, basically the same but with some different wording in the collection of Dan stories from Liberia that Won Ldy-Paye and Margaret Lippert wrote with illustrations by Ashley Bryan: Why Leopard Has Spots.

itemRows.title: Why Leopard has spots : Dan stories from Liberia
Item 11
itemRows.content: Here's Ashley Bryan's depiction of the chicken and the crocodile:

itemRows.title: Ashley Bryan Illustration 3 For Why The Leopard Has No Spots
Item 13
itemRows.content:
You'll find six stories here: Why Leopard Has Spots, Mrs. Chicken and the Hungry Crocodile, The Talking Vegetables, The Hunger Season, Why Spider Has a Big Butt, and Spider Flies to the Feast. In the very moving introduction to that book, Won Ldy-Paye explains that his grandmother died in 1995, knowing that her grandson was bringing the storytelling traditions of the Dan people to new audiences in a different part of the world (Ldy-Paye had to flee Liberia during the civil war in which both his father and his older brother were killed.) In the note for the Mrs. Chicken story in this book, Ldy-Paye adds that the story was a favorite of his younger brother, so the way that he tells it comes both from his grandmother and from his brother.

Ldy-Paye's grandmother and his brother shaped this story into something that is distinctively different from other versions of the "chicken-and-crocodile-both-lay-eggs" type of story. In Ldy-Paye's story, the chicken is a trickster: she swaps the eggs without the crocodile realizing what she has done, and when she offers to exchange their offspring, the crocodile is grateful, as if she is actually doing him a favor. She is only pretending to be the crocodile's sister when she says "Sisters help each other," because as soon as the chicken gets free she vows never to go near the crocodile ever again; she is not the crocodile's sister.

So the story concludes with the chicken taking a bath in a little puddle instead of going to the river, and that's why chickens bathe in puddles to this day.

In other versions of this story, however, the focus is more on the crocodile and the lesson that he learns: when he finally realizes that both he and the the chicken lay eggs, he realizes that the chicken belongs to his family, which means the chicken is not his enemy. You can find this story in Dennett's Notes on the Folklore of the Fjort, "Why the Crocodile Does Not Eat the Hen," and I did a 100-word version of that one (click on the image for larger view), but be sure to look at Dennett's version for all the details (including a reference to the god Nzambi).

itemRows.title: Page From Mrs. Chicken. And The Hungry Crocodile
Item 14

itemRows.title: Mrs. Chicken and the hungry crocodile
Item 4
itemRows.content: The beautiful illustrations for this book are by Julie Paschkis, and you can see how the illustrations, text, layout, everything works together, as in this 2-page spread:

itemRows.title: Item 5
itemRows.content: You might remember that we read a collaboration by Ldy-Paye, Lippert, and Paschkis several months ago, back in June: The Talking Vegetables.

itemRows.title: Item 8
itemRows.content:
One of my favorite things about this book is that Ldy-Paye lets us know that he learned this story from his grandmother, who told him other stories from the Dan storytelling traditions of Liberia.

I also want to note that you can find the story of Mrs. Chicken, basically the same but with some different wording in the collection of Dan stories from Liberia that Won Ldy-Paye and Margaret Lippert wrote with illustrations by Ashley Bryan: Why Leopard Has Spots.

itemRows.title: Why Leopard has spots : Dan stories from Liberia
Item 11
itemRows.content: Here's Ashley Bryan's depiction of the chicken and the crocodile:

itemRows.title: Ashley Bryan Illustration 3 For Why The Leopard Has No Spots
Item 13
itemRows.content:
You'll find six stories here: Why Leopard Has Spots, Mrs. Chicken and the Hungry Crocodile, The Talking Vegetables, The Hunger Season, Why Spider Has a Big Butt, and Spider Flies to the Feast. In the very moving introduction to that book, Won Ldy-Paye explains that his grandmother died in 1995, knowing that her grandson was bringing the storytelling traditions of the Dan people to new audiences in a different part of the world (Ldy-Paye had to flee Liberia during the civil war in which both his father and his older brother were killed.) In the note for the Mrs. Chicken story in this book, Ldy-Paye adds that the story was a favorite of his younger brother, so the way that he tells it comes both from his grandmother and from his brother.

Ldy-Paye's grandmother and his brother shaped this story into something that is distinctively different from other versions of the "chicken-and-crocodile-both-lay-eggs" type of story. In Ldy-Paye's story, the chicken is a trickster: she swaps the eggs without the crocodile realizing what she has done, and when she offers to exchange their offspring, the crocodile is grateful, as if she is actually doing him a favor. She is only pretending to be the crocodile's sister when she says "Sisters help each other," because as soon as the chicken gets free she vows never to go near the crocodile ever again; she is not the crocodile's sister.

So the story concludes with the chicken taking a bath in a little puddle instead of going to the river, and that's why chickens bathe in puddles to this day.

In other versions of this story, however, the focus is more on the crocodile and the lesson that he learns: when he finally realizes that both he and the the chicken lay eggs, he realizes that the chicken belongs to his family, which means the chicken is not his enemy. You can find this story in Dennett's Notes on the Folklore of the Fjort, "Why the Crocodile Does Not Eat the Hen," and I did a 100-word version of that one (click on the image for larger view), but be sure to look at Dennett's version for all the details (including a reference to the god Nzambi).

itemRows.title: Page From Mrs. Chicken. And The Hungry Crocodile
Notes on the folklore of the Fjort (French Congo)
Crocodile And The Hen (short Version) Laura Gibbs
Item 16
itemRows.content: There's a children's book version based on the story as reported in Dennett's book: Crocodile and Hen: A Bakongo Folktale by Joan M. Lexau, with illustrations by Doug Cushman. Like the version in Dennett, here the crocodile gets schooled by his friend, the wise lizard.

itemRows.title: Crocodile and hen : a Bakongo folktale
Item 18
itemRows.content:
If there are any teachers out there reading this post, my guess is that you could do compare-and-constrast with these two children's books, even with very young readers, helping them to see how storytellers each make their own choices, and then to speculate about just why storytellers choose the details that they do.

I did a readers theater version of the crocodile-and-the-hen, following the Bakongo version where the crocodile goes to seek an answer to his question and ends up consulting with the lizard; you can read my version of the story The Crocodile and the Chicken (CC-licensed for teachers to reuse, rewrite as needed!).

There's also a very different type of story told with this same "we all lay eggs" motif in which the plot revolves around male characters; this story comes from the Yao people of Malawi as published by H. Stannus in 1917: The Cock and the Crocodile. This story ends up providing an explanation for why crocodiles and humans are enemies: we, after all, do not lay eggs.

itemRows.title: Page From The Cock And The Crocodile
Item 21
itemRows.content:
To finish up, I wanted to share this lovely video with Won-Ldy Paye talking about the art of storytelling: It Takes a Village to Tell a Story.

So, you might not have a village with a storyteller on the verandah, a storyteller who is a "walking library" as Paye says... but we do have the Internet Archive, and Won-Ldy Paye's books await you there!

itemRows.title: Won Ldy Paye Talking About The Art Of Storytelling
heycock header
itemRows.content: Cambridge student David Heycock speaking in favor of the proposition

itemRows.title: Item 6
itemRows.content:
David Heycock, concluding remarks

Amerian society has felt fit to use Negro labor. It has felt fit to use the blood of the Negro in two world wars. It has felt fit to listen to his music. It has felt fit to listen to his jokes. And yet as far as i'm concerned it has never felt fit to give the American Negro a fair deal. And for this reason Mr. President, I will beg leave to propose the motion that the American Dream is at the expense of the American Negro.

itemRows.title: burford header
itemRows.content: Jeremy Burford, Cambridge student, speaking against the motion

itemRows.title: Item 10
itemRows.content:
Jeremy Burford, concluding remarks

This debate tonight concerns whether the American Dream is at the expense of the American Negro. That is whether the American Negro has paid for the American Dream with his suffering or whether the American Dream has furthered Negro inequality. And I would deny those two precepts. I would say that Negro inequality has hindered the American Dream and I would say that the American Dream has been very important indeed in furthering civil rights and in furthering freedom for the American Negro. Mr. President, Sir, I beg to oppose the motion.

itemRows.title: baldwin header
itemRows.content: James Baldwin speaking in favor of the motion

itemRows.title: baldwin concluding
itemRows.content:
James Baldwin, concluding remarks

It is a terrible thing for an entire people to surrender to the notion that one ninth of its population is beneath them. And until that moment, until the moment comes, when, we the Americans, we the American people, are able to accept the fact, that i have to accept for example, and my ancestors are both white and black, that on that continent we are trying to forge a new identity for which we need each other, and that i'm not a ward of America. I'm not an object of missionary charity. I'm one of the people who built the country. Until this moment there is scarcely any hope for the American Dream because the people who are denied participation in it by their very presence will wreck it. And if that happens it's a very grave moment for the west. Thank you.

itemRows.title: buckley header
itemRows.content: William Buckley speaking in opposition to the motion

itemRows.title: Buckley concludes
itemRows.content:
William Buckley, concluding remarks

But the fundamental friend of the Negro people in the United States is the good nature and is the generosity and is the good wishes, is the decency, the fundamental decency that do lie at the reserves of the spirit of the American people. These must not be laughed at. Under no circumstances must they be laughed at and under no circumstances must America be addressed and told that the only alternative to the staus quo is to overthrow that civilization which we consider to be the faith of our fathers, the faith indeed of your fathers. This is what must animate whatever ameliorism must come because if it finally does come to a confrontation, a radical confrontation between giving up what we understand to be the best features of the American way of life which at that level, as far as i can see, is indistinguishable from the European way of life, then we will fight the issue. And we will fight the issue in the Cambridge Union, but we will fight it as you were once recently called to do on beaches and on hills and on mountains and on landing grounds. And we will be convinced that just as you won the war against a particular threat to civilization you were nevertheless waging a war in favor of and for the benefit of Germans, your own enemies, just as we are convinced that if it should ever come to that kind of a confrontation, our own determination to win the struggle, will be a determination to wage a war not only for whites but also for Negroes.

itemRows.title: intro header
itemRows.content: Introduction to the debate

itemRows.title: britannic phase text
itemRows.content:
The Encyclopedia Britannica Phase, 1980-81

In 1980 when I was trying to figure out the next stage of my life, I spent the first six months working nights as a waiter and my days reading in the Santa Monica Library. Early on, the work being done at the Architecture Machine Group lab at MIT (e.g. the Movie Manual and the Aspen Movie Map and the interactive laserdiscs being produced by MCA/IBM (eg. The First National Kidisc) caught my attention and I decided to focus on the utterly wild idea of an Intelligent Encyclopedia that could interact with users at their level of interest and ability. In large part through blind luck I ended up being hired as a consultant to Encyclopedia Brittanica and got to spend six months. The luck arose as a result of a letter I wrote to Dennis Hadley at Random House inquiring about the possibility of licensing the Random House Encyclopedia. Dennis had been the sales rep who called on me when I ran Liberation Books in Seattle and went on to be the VP of sales. A friend asked me what I was into at that point in my life and I sent her a copy of the letter, completely unaware (honest) that her father was on Britannica’s board. She gave the letter to her father who in turn gave it to Chuck Swanson, Britannica’s CEO. Swanson called me up and said “If you know so much why don’t you come talk to us.” In reality at that point I didn’t know much of anything, but i found the one guy in the U.S., Rod Daynes at the University of Nebraska, who had made a bunch of interactive discs for the CIA and invited him to go with me to Chicago to do a presentation for Swanson and Charles van Doren (yes the Quiz Show contestant) who was the head of editorial. Rod Daynes put on a flawless demonstration and I got hired to write the paper below with Charles van Doren as my editor and project cheerleader.

itemRows.title: EB paper text
itemRows.content:
Encyclopedia Britannica and

The Intellectual Tools of the Future

A key idea in this paper, that propelled my work forward for the next many years was a new definition of a book -- one which  focused on the way a book is USED, rather than its physical nature. I realized that in 1981 books might be considered a user-controlled medium because readers controlled both pace and sequence of access; in contrast to audio and video which at that time were entirely producer-controlled in that pace and sequence was set by the maker. But this was the moment that digital control was becoming a factor in all audio and video playback meaning that all media would soon start to resemble books in terms of user-control. That plus the understanding that the internet and artificial intelligence were coming made the moment seem ripe for a daring re-conception of what learning could be in the digital era.

itemRows.title: Atari documents text
itemRows.content:
The Atari Documents 1981-83

When I finished the Britannica gig I basically sent the paper to anyone I thought might be interested enough to hire me to work on a related project. Since I had written in the paper that the future Britannica might be a joint venture with Xerox (Parc) and Lucas Film, when Alan Kay left Xerox to become Atari’s chief scientist, I contacted him right away. Alan invited me up to Atari, read all 120 pages while i was sitting there, looked up and said, “This is exactly the sort of project I want to work on here. Why don’t you join me in the research group?”It’s interesting to read these docs now. Our vision (and it was a collective one) was boundless but also idealistic . . . in the sense that while we imagined a much richer media landscape than the one we now have, forty-plus years later, we completely missed the potential power of the network to harness the efforts of people in their millions . . . we were still basically stuck in the print era construct of central editorial body commissioning experts and funding rich multimedia and AI components. We literally couldn’t have imagined the wikipedia at that time. What would be interesting to look at now would be how to consider how to integrate some of the blue-sky ideas we generated into the current landscape.

It’s interesting to read these docs now. Our vision (and it was a collective one) was boundless but also idealistic . . . in the sense that while we imagined a much richer media landscape than the one we now have, forty-plus years later, we completely missed the potential power of the network to harness the efforts of people in their millions . . . we were still basically stuck in the print era construct of central editorial body commissioning experts and funding rich multimedia and AI components. We literally couldn’t have imagined the wikipedia at that time. What would be interesting to look at now would be how to consider how to integrate some of the blue-sky ideas we generated into the current landscape.

itemRows.title: Atari Drawings text
itemRows.content:
The Atari Drawings

One of the sadder facts about Atari was that the executives at Warner really had no idea of Atari’s potential, particularly the remarkable assortment of creative brain power Alan Kay had assembled in the research group. In 1982 a delegation of Warner execs came to visit and Brenda Laurel and I tried to come up with a way to explain the Encyclopedia Project. We designed a series of scenarios and Alan Kay arranged for Glen Keane, the famous Disney animator to render them in these charming drawings. I have no recollection of their response but am amazed to see how prescient they were.

itemRows.title: CVD visits text
itemRows.content:
Charles Van Doren visits the Atari Research Group

In December of 1982 we brought Charles van Doren to Atari for a two-day seminar with the Encyclopedia project. These are the notes from that meeting.

itemRows.title: Whither doc text
itemRows.content:
Whither the Encyclopedia Project, AKA, The Do It! memo.

When you look at the scope of what was being proposed, you can imagine how exciting it was to be told simply to Do It!  Atari imploded shortly thereafter (thanks in part to the utter failure of Atari’s ET game) so the research group disbanded and the dream of an Intelligent Encyclopedia landed on the shelf of dreams (at least temporarily).

itemRows.title: Ifugao text
itemRows.content:
The Ifugao Question Journal

We imagined an encyclopedia so “complete” you could ask any question and get a useful answer. Unfortunately, we had no idea of the range of questions people might ask — remember this was more than a decade before Yahoo and sixteen years before Google. Most questions that occurred to you would flit quickly out of consciousness because you knew getting an answer would be impossible or not worth the effort. So, we bought a bunch of micro-tape recorders which we gave to people and asked them to be conscious of those fleeting questions and record them.  Michael Naimark, one of my colleagues at the lab took some tape recorders to a rural area of the Philippines. This is his report.

itemRows.title: Bolter Letter
itemRows.content:
Letter

from Jay David Bolter one of the first humanities scholars to embrace the potential of digital technology to Steve Weyer, a key member of the Atari Encyclopedia Project

itemRows.title: Movie Manual text
itemRows.content:
Movie Manual

When I first saw this at MIT it blew my mind on two counts. Anti-aliasing had just been developed in the lab and this was the first time anyone had seen decent looking text on a TV screen (the quality of the video doesn’t come close to how good it looked in situ). Also the first time the video appears on what otherwise looks like a normal book page (about 2:20 in the video) it expanded our notion of the page to include audio and video — i.e. the affordances of a book but with the addition of time-based media.

itemRows.title: Encyclopedia And The Intellectual Tools Of The Future . . . November 1981
Atari . . . Ifugao Question Journal, Michael Naimark
Exchange With Steve Weyer And J. David Bolter 1983

from Jay David Bolter one of the first humanities scholars to embrace the potential of digital technology to Steve Weyer, a key member of the Atari Encyclopedia Project

itemRows.title: Movie Manual text
itemRows.content:
Movie Manual

When I first saw this at MIT it blew my mind on two counts. Anti-aliasing had just been developed in the lab and this was the first time anyone had seen decent looking text on a TV screen (the quality of the video doesn’t come close to how good it looked in situ). Also the first time the video appears on what otherwise looks like a normal book page (about 2:20 in the video) it expanded our notion of the page to include audio and video — i.e. the affordances of a book but with the addition of time-based media.
